title: Basic Operators
content:
## What are Operators?

Operators are special symbols that perform operations on values and variables.

## Arithmetic Operators

```python
a = 10
b = 3

# Addition
print(a + b)   # 13

# Subtraction
print(a - b)   # 7

# Multiplication
print(a * b)   # 30

# Division (always returns float)
print(a / b)   # 3.3333...

# Floor Division (rounds down to nearest integer)
print(a // b)  # 3

# Modulus (remainder)
print(a % b)   # 1 (10 = 3*3 + 1)

# Exponentiation (power)
print(a ** b)  # 1000 (10^3)
```

### Floor Division Details

```python
# Floor division always rounds toward negative infinity
print(7 // 2)    # 3
print(-7 // 2)   # -4 (not -3!)
print(7.5 // 2)  # 3.0 (returns float if operand is float)
```

### Modulus Details

```python
# Modulus returns the remainder
print(17 % 5)   # 2
print(20 % 4)   # 0 (evenly divisible)
print(-17 % 5)  # 3 (Python's modulus always returns non-negative)

# Common uses
if number % 2 == 0:
    print("Even")
else:
    print("Odd")
```

## Comparison Operators

```python
a = 10
b = 5
c = 10

# Equal to
print(a == b)   # False
print(a == c)   # True

# Not equal to
print(a != b)   # True
print(a != c)   # False

# Greater than
print(a > b)    # True
print(a > c)    # False

# Less than
print(a < b)    # False
print(b < a)    # True

# Greater than or equal to
print(a >= c)   # True
print(a >= b)   # True

# Less than or equal to
print(b <= a)   # True
print(a <= c)   # True
```

### Comparing Strings

```python
# Strings are compared lexicographically (alphabetically)
print("apple" < "banana")   # True
print("Apple" < "apple")    # True (uppercase comes before lowercase)
print("abc" == "abc")       # True
print("10" < "9")           # True (string comparison, not numeric!)
```

## Logical Operators

```python
x = True
y = False

# and - True if both are True
print(x and y)    # False
print(x and True) # True

# or - True if at least one is True
print(x or y)     # True
print(y or False) # False

# not - Inverts the value
print(not x)      # False
print(not y)      # True
```

## Membership Operators

```python
fruits = ["apple", "banana"]

# in
print("apple" in fruits)  # True
print("orange" in fruits) # False

# not in
print("orange" not in fruits) # True
```

## Identity Operators

```python
# is - Returns True if both variables are the same object
a = [1, 2, 3]
b = [1, 2, 3]
c = a

print(a == b)  # True (values are same)
print(a is b)  # False (different objects in memory)
print(a is c)  # True (same object)
```
code:
# Basic Operators - Examples

# Arithmetic Operators
print("Arithmetic Operators")
print("="*40)
a, b = 17, 5

print(f"{a} + {b} = {a + b}")       # Addition
print(f"{a} - {b} = {a - b}")       # Subtraction
print(f"{a} * {b} = {a * b}")       # Multiplication
print(f"{a} / {b} = {a / b}")       # Division
print(f"{a} // {b} = {a // b}")     # Floor Division
print(f"{a} % {b} = {a % b}")       # Modulus
print(f"{a} ** {b} = {a ** b}")     # Exponentiation

# Comparison Operators
print("\nComparison Operators")
print("="*40)
x, y = 10, 20

print(f"{x} == {y}: {x == y}")
print(f"{x} != {y}: {x != y}")
print(f"{x} > {y}: {x > y}")
print(f"{x} < {y}: {x < y}")
print(f"{x} >= {x}: {x >= x}")
print(f"{x} <= {y}: {x <= y}")

# Logical Operators
print("\nLogical Operators")
print("="*40)
p, q = True, False

print(f"True and False = {p and q}")
print(f"True or False = {p or q}")
print(f"not True = {not p}")
print(f"not False = {not q}")

# Practical example
age = 25
has_license = True
print(f"\nAge: {age}, Has License: {has_license}")
print(f"Can drive? {age >= 16 and has_license}")

# Membership Operators
print("\nMembership Operators")
print("="*40)
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]

print(f"List: {fruits}")
print(f"'apple' in list: {'apple' in fruits}")
print(f"'grape' in list: {'grape' in fruits}")
print(f"'grape' not in list: {'grape' not in fruits}")

# Identity Operators
print("\nIdentity Operators")
print("="*40)
list1 = [1, 2, 3]
list2 = [1, 2, 3]
list3 = list1

print(f"list1 == list2: {list1 == list2} (same values)")
print(f"list1 is list2: {list1 is list2} (same object)")
print(f"list1 is list3: {list1 is list3} (same object)")

# Operator Precedence
print("\nOperator Precedence")
print("="*40)
print(f"2 + 3 * 4 = {2 + 3 * 4} (not 20!)")
print(f"(2 + 3) * 4 = {(2 + 3) * 4}")
